Situation1: They actively help a mentee navigate a challenging project with regular check-ins and feedback.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in. My mentee, Sarah, had just messaged me, anxious about her project’s looming deadline. She needed my guidance, and I’d promised her a check-in this afternoon. But at the same time, my headset buzzed with the voice of Mr. Jenkins, a long-time customer, his tone sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t another scam?” he demanded, his frustration palpable. My script urged me to stay calm, address his objections, and keep him on the line. Yet, my mind kept drifting to Sarah, picturing her waiting for my feedback, counting on me to help her through her confusion. I felt my chest tighten, torn between the expectation to be a patient, attentive mentor and the pressure to be a persuasive, unflappable telemarketer. Both needed me, right now, in completely different ways. My hands hovered over the keyboard, my heart pounding as I wrestled with which role to answer first, knowing I couldn’t give my best to both at once.
